summary:
After the Spanish-American War, the U.S. took control of the Philippines, angering Filipino nationalists who had declared their independence. Fighting broke out in 1899, with Filipinos first using regular army tactics, then switching to guerrilla warfare. The U.S. won in 1902, but some groups kept fighting for years.

The war was brutal, with many civilian deaths from disease and U.S. reprisals. It changed the Philippines, bringing in Protestantism and English as the main language. The U.S. later granted the Philippines self-rule and then independence in 1946.
